Freelance Career Planner

Starting Your Freelance Journey

Growing Your Freelance Business

Mastering Your Freelance Career

Your current stage of growth reveals where to focus, what to avoid, and how to keep moving forward with clarity and confidence.
$60k or less

You represent of freelancers in the early stages of their career.

At this stage, you're taking your first steps into freelancing. This is a crucial time for learning, building your portfolio, and establishing your initial client base. Focus on gaining practical experience and building a foundation for future growth.

What should you do next?

  • Focus on building a strong portfolio with quality projects.

  • Consider offering competitive rates to attract initial clients.

  • Invest time in networking and establishing your online presence.

$60k - $120k

You're among of freelancers who are stepping into an exciting phase of stability and growth.

At this income level, you're establishing yourself as a professional freelancer. You have a solid portfolio and can command higher rates for specialized skills. Focus on building long-term client relationships and developing a niche expertise to further increase your value.

What should you do next?

  • Consider creating productized service packages to streamline your offerings

  • Start building a small network of trusted colleagues for referrals and collaboration

  • Invest in advanced training to develop specialized skills that command premium rates

$120k - $250k

You're in the top of expert freelancers, consistently raising the bar for excellence.

Congratulations! You've reached an expert income level that puts you in the top tier of freelancers. Your specialized skills and experience command premium rates. At this stage, focus on optimizing your business model, potentially scaling beyond just your own hours, and working with high-value clients on impactful projects.

What should you do next?

  • Consider developing passive income streams like digital products or courses

  • Explore building a small agency or bringing on subcontractors for larger projects

  • Position yourself as a thought leader through speaking, writing, or consulting

Suggested for you

Positioning for Designers

Knowing where clients look, what they value, and how to position your services helps you stand out and attract the right opportunities.

Where are clients already looking for freelance designers like you?

Freelance clients are already looking for you ‚Äî the key is to show up where they‚Äôre searching and make it easy to say yes.

Portfolio Websites

Clients often Google phrases like ‚Äúfreelance branding designer‚Äù or ‚Äúweb designer near me.‚Äù Make sure your personal website includes these phrases in headings, page titles, and case study summaries. Add testimonials, niche keywords, and clear calls to action to improve discoverability and conversion.

Design Showcases

Visual platforms are where clients scout for aesthetics and taste. Upload polished visuals, focus on niche consistency (e.g. mobile apps, minimalist branding), and link directly to your portfolio. These platforms build trust ‚Äî not traffic ‚Äî so they work best when paired with a strong personal site.

Creative Agency Referrals

Agencies frequently look for trusted freelancers to handle overflow work. Reach out with a curated portfolio and position yourself as a reliable extension of their team. Once you‚Äôre in the loop, referrals can become a steady source of qualified work.

Why do clients hire freelance designers?

Brands need to stand out in crowded markets with polished, professional visuals ‚Äî whether it's a logo, website, app interface, or social media graphic. Clients are looking for designers who can create strategic, conversion-driven visuals, not just ‚Äúpretty pictures.‚Äù

How to get more clients
How to position yourself

Focus on the business goals behind your design work ‚Äî like increasing signups, improving user experience, or elevating brand perception. Show before/after examples, explain your process, and tailor your portfolio to your ideal client‚Äôs industry or style.

Marketers often get hired after the brand or product is built. Stay connected with creatives and founders in your network ‚Äî they‚Äôre often the first to hear about client needs. Even a simple ‚ÄúHey, I know someone great for that‚Äù can lead to high-quality referrals.

LinkedIn Search & Organic Posts

Founders, CMOs, and agencies search LinkedIn for specific skill sets like ‚Äúemail marketing strategist‚Äù or ‚Äúpaid ads freelancer.‚Äù Make sure your headline is specific and client-facing, and post mini case studies or behind-the-scenes wins to position yourself as a results-oriented pro.

Why do clients hire freelance marketers?

Businesses need measurable results ‚Äî leads, conversions, and long-term growth ‚Äî not just visibility. Clients hire freelance marketers who can build smart strategies, manage campaigns across channels, and translate data into revenue-driving decisions.

How to get more clients
How to position yourself

Position yourself as a results-driven strategist, not just an executor. Showcase specific outcomes like increased conversions or reduced ad costs, explain your thought process, and align your services with the business goals your ideal clients care about most.

Positioning for Photographers

Knowing where clients look, what they value, and how to position your services helps you stand out and attract the right opportunities.

Where are clients already looking for freelance photographers like you?

Freelance clients are already looking for you ‚Äî the key is to show up where they‚Äôre searching and make it easy to say yes.

Google Search & Local SEO

Clients often search phrases like ‚Äúevent photographer near me‚Äù or ‚Äúproduct photographer in [city].‚Äù Make sure your website has those exact phrases in headings, and set up a Google Business Profile with recent reviews and images to appear in map results.

Referrals from Venues, Event Planners, or Brands

Many businesses rely on trusted partners to find photographers. Build relationships with event coordinators, local venues, and design studios ‚Äî they‚Äôre often asked for referrals and love recommending people they trust.

Instagram with Location & Niche Hashtags

Visual proof is everything. Share work consistently, use geo-specific hashtags (e.g. #nycphotographer), and write captions that describe the project and results. Keep a link to your booking page or portfolio in your bio ‚Äî make it easy to take the next step.

Why do clients hire freelance photographers?

In a visual-first world, strong imagery can define a brand‚Äôs identity and instantly build trust. Clients hire freelance photographers to capture professional, high-quality photos that reflect their brand and elevate their online presence ‚Äî not just fill space.

How to get more clients
How to position yourself

Show how your photography supports brand identity, drives engagement, or tells a compelling story. Focus on style consistency, highlight real-world usage (e.g. websites, ads, packaging), and present your work in a clean, professional portfolio that matches your clients‚Äô aesthetic.

Positioning for Video Creators

Knowing where clients look, what they value, and how to position your services helps you stand out and attract the right opportunities.

Where are clients already looking for freelance video creators like you?

Freelance clients are already looking for you ‚Äî the key is to show up where they‚Äôre searching and make it easy to say yes.

Referrals from Agencies or Marketers

Video is rarely a standalone request ‚Äî it often comes through a designer, marketing team, or brand strategist. Make sure your contacts in those fields know what kind of video work you do and who you do it for. A quick ‚ÄúDo you have anyone who does this?‚Äù message can unlock high-trust projects.

YouTube or Portfolio Reel

Clients want to see your editing style, pacing, and tone ‚Äî not just read about it. Create a polished, skimmable demo reel on your site or YouTube channel. Include your niche (e.g. SaaS explainers, product launches) in the title and description for SEO and clarity.

LinkedIn & Social Video Content

Founders and CMOs love short-form case studies and before/after video transformations. Share bite-sized breakdowns or quick wins in feed posts. Video has an edge in visibility, so even short behind-the-scenes clips can help you stay top-of-mind.

Why do clients hire freelance video creators?

Video is one of the most powerful tools for education, storytelling, and engagement. Clients hire freelance video creators to turn abstract ideas into emotional, persuasive content that keeps viewers watching and drives action across platforms.

How to get more clients
How to position yourself

Position your work as a tool for engagement, education, or storytelling ‚Äî not just visuals. Share metrics where possible (like watch time or conversions), explain the strategy behind each piece, and showcase your best work in a tightly edited reel tailored to your niche.

There's a better way than hourly billing

Using an hourly rate can be a helpful way to create internal estimates ‚Äî but when it comes to proposals, daily, weekly, or project-based pricing is often more effective. It sets clearer expectations, emphasizes outcomes over effort, and helps clients focus on the value you deliver ‚Äî not the time it takes.

Starting Your Freelance Journey

Growing Your Freelance Business

Mastering Your Freelance Career

You represent of freelancers in the early stages of their career.
You're among of freelancers who are stepping into an exciting phase of stability and growth.
You're in the top of expert freelancers, consistently raising the bar for excellence.
Income Bracket: $60k or less
Income Bracket: $60k - $120k
Income Bracket: $120k - $250k
At this stage, you're taking your first steps into freelancing. This is a crucial time for learning, building your portfolio, and establishing your initial client base. Focus on gaining practical experience and building a foundation for future growth.
At this income level, you're establishing yourself as a professional freelancer. You have a solid portfolio and can command higher rates for specialized skills. Focus on building long-term client relationships and developing a niche expertise to further increase your value.
Congratulations! You've reached an expert income level that puts you in the top tier of freelancers. Your specialized skills and experience command premium rates. At this stage, focus on optimizing your business model, potentially scaling beyond just your own hours, and working with high-value clients on impactful projects.
What should you do next?

  • Focus on building a strong portfolio with quality projects.

  • Consider offering competitive rates to attract initial clients.

  • Invest time in networking and establishing your online presence.

  • Consider creating productized service packages to streamline your offerings

  • Start building a small network of trusted colleagues for referrals and collaboration

  • Invest in advanced training to develop specialized skills that command premium rates

  • Consider developing passive income streams like digital products or courses

  • Explore building a small agency or bringing on subcontractors for larger projects

  • Position yourself as a thought leader through speaking, writing, or consulting

Positioning for Photographers

Positioning for Video Creators

Knowing where clients look, what they value, and how to position your services helps you stand out and attract the right opportunities.
Where are clients already looking for freelance designers like you?
Where are clients already looking for freelance developers like you?
Where are clients already looking for freelance writers like you?
Where are clients already looking for freelance marketers like you?
Where are clients already looking for freelance photographers like you?
Where are clients already looking for freelance video creators like you?
The smartest way to find freelance work is to show up where clients are already looking ‚Äî and position your services around what they value most. When you understand their goals and make it easy to say yes, the right opportunities come to you.
Portfolio Websites
Clients often Google phrases like ‚Äúfreelance branding designer‚Äù or ‚Äúweb designer near me.‚Äù Make sure your personal website includes these phrases in headings, page titles, and case study summaries. Add testimonials, niche keywords, and clear calls to action to improve discoverability and conversion.
Design Showcases
Visual platforms are where clients scout for aesthetics and taste. Upload polished visuals, focus on niche consistency (e.g. mobile apps, minimalist branding), and link directly to your portfolio. These platforms build trust ‚Äî not traffic ‚Äî so they work best when paired with a strong personal site.
Creative Agency Referrals
Agencies frequently look for trusted freelancers to handle overflow work. Reach out with a curated portfolio and position yourself as a reliable extension of their team. Once you‚Äôre in the loop, referrals can become a steady source of qualified work.
LinkedIn Search & Referrals
Clients often ask for developer referrals on LinkedIn or search by keywords like ‚Äúfreelance web developer.‚Äù Keep your headline and summary clear, use job-specific keywords, and share recent work to stay top-of-mind. Ask happy clients to comment on or share your posts to boost visibility.
Portfolio Website with Technical SEO
Tech-savvy clients often use Google to find developers by stack, industry, or project type. Make sure your site includes searchable phrases like ‚ÄúReact developer for SaaS startups‚Äù or ‚ÄúNode.js developer for MVPs.‚Äù Case studies and blog posts can help signal expertise before a discovery call.
Developer Communities & Forums
Communities like Indie Hackers, dev-focused Slack groups, and private Discord servers often host clients who prefer direct referrals. Be helpful, not salesy ‚Äî share insights, answer questions, and let your expertise naturally attract attention.
Your Website (with Niche Landing Pages)
Marketing clients often skim multiple freelancer sites before reaching out. Build specific service pages ‚Äî e.g. ‚ÄúEmail Flows for Shopify Brands‚Äù or ‚ÄúSEO Audits for B2B SaaS‚Äù ‚Äî to match what clients are already searching for. The more tailored the page, the more likely you‚Äôll be seen as ‚Äúthe one.‚Äù
Referrals from Designers, Developers, or Founders
Marketers often get hired after the brand or product is built. Stay connected with creatives and founders in your network ‚Äî they‚Äôre often the first to hear about client needs. Even a simple ‚ÄúHey, I know someone great for that‚Äù can lead to high-quality referrals.
LinkedIn Search & Organic Posts
Founders, CMOs, and agencies search LinkedIn for specific skill sets like ‚Äúemail marketing strategist‚Äù or ‚Äúpaid ads freelancer.‚Äù Make sure your headline is specific and client-facing, and post mini case studies or behind-the-scenes wins to position yourself as a results-oriented pro.
Your Website (SEO-optimized)
Clients search for things like ‚Äúsales page copywriter‚Äù or ‚Äúfreelance writer for SaaS.‚Äù Make sure your website has clear service pages, niche keywords, and examples of your work. Including short summaries of past results ‚Äî like increased conversions or improved clarity ‚Äî can build instant trust.
LinkedIn Posts & Comments
Clients follow and engage with content creators in their niche. Share writing insights, client results, or breakdowns of good vs. bad copy. Comment thoughtfully on posts from marketers, founders, and agency owners ‚Äî many copywriting jobs start in the comments.
Marketing & Branding Agency Referrals
Agencies need dependable copywriters for web, email, and product launches. Reach out to designers and marketers directly with samples that show you can fit their clients‚Äô tone and timeline. Partnerships like these can unlock steady project pipelines.
Google Search & Local SEO
Clients often search phrases like ‚Äúevent photographer near me‚Äù or ‚Äúproduct photographer in [city].‚Äù Make sure your website has those exact phrases in headings, and set up a Google Business Profile with recent reviews and images to appear in map results.
Referrals from Venues, Event Planners, or Brands
Many businesses rely on trusted partners to find photographers. Build relationships with event coordinators, local venues, and design studios ‚Äî they‚Äôre often asked for referrals and love recommending people they trust.
Instagram with Location & Niche Hashtags
Visual proof is everything. Share work consistently, use geo-specific hashtags (e.g. #nycphotographer), and write captions that describe the project and results. Keep a link to your booking page or portfolio in your bio ‚Äî make it easy to take the next step.
Referrals from Agencies or Marketers
Video is rarely a standalone request ‚Äî it often comes through a designer, marketing team, or brand strategist. Make sure your contacts in those fields know what kind of video work you do and who you do it for. A quick ‚ÄúDo you have anyone who does this?‚Äù message can unlock high-trust projects.
YouTube or Portfolio Reel
Clients want to see your editing style, pacing, and tone ‚Äî not just read about it. Create a polished, skimmable demo reel on your site or YouTube channel. Include your niche (e.g. SaaS explainers, product launches) in the title and description for SEO and clarity.
LinkedIn & Social Video Content
Founders and CMOs love short-form case studies and before/after video transformations. Share bite-sized breakdowns or quick wins in feed posts. Video has an edge in visibility, so even short behind-the-scenes clips can help you stay top-of-mind.

Positioning for Photographers

Positioning for Video Creators

Knowing where clients look, what they value, and how to position your services helps you stand out and attract the right opportunities.
Why do clients hire freelance designers?
Why do clients hire freelance developers?
Why do clients hire freelance writers?
Why do clients hire freelance marketers?
Why do clients hire freelance photographers?
Why do clients hire freelance video creators?
Brands need to stand out in crowded markets with polished, professional visuals ‚Äî whether it's a logo, website, app interface, or social media graphic. Clients are looking for designers who can create strategic, conversion-driven visuals, not just ‚Äúpretty pictures.‚Äù
Brands need reliable, scalable technology to support their products, websites, and internal tools. Clients hire freelance developers who can bring ideas to life efficiently, write clean maintainable code, and solve real-world problems ‚Äî not just execute on a list of features.
Clear, persuasive messaging is essential for turning browsers into buyers. Clients hire freelance copywriters who can write words that resonate, clarify complex ideas, and move people to take action ‚Äî whether it‚Äôs through web copy, emails, or sales pages.
Businesses need measurable results ‚Äî leads, conversions, and long-term growth ‚Äî not just visibility. Clients hire freelance marketers who can build smart strategies, manage campaigns across channels, and translate data into revenue-driving decisions.
In a visual-first world, strong imagery can define a brand‚Äôs identity and instantly build trust. Clients hire freelance photographers to capture professional, high-quality photos that reflect their brand and elevate their online presence ‚Äî not just fill space.
How to position yourself
Focus on the business goals behind your design work ‚Äî like increasing signups, improving user experience, or elevating brand perception. Show before/after examples, explain your process, and tailor your portfolio to your ideal client‚Äôs industry or style.
Focus on the problems your code solves ‚Äî like improving performance, streamlining workflows, or launching new products. Highlight real-world outcomes, share code samples or walkthroughs, and tailor your messaging to the types of clients or platforms you specialize in.
Emphasize the impact your words have ‚Äî whether it‚Äôs boosting conversions, simplifying complex ideas, or strengthening brand voice. Include before/after examples, talk through your writing strategy, and tailor samples to the industries or formats you want to be hired for.
Position yourself as a results-driven strategist, not just an executor. Showcase specific outcomes like increased conversions or reduced ad costs, explain your thought process, and align your services with the business goals your ideal clients care about most.
Show how your photography supports brand identity, drives engagement, or tells a compelling story. Focus on style consistency, highlight real-world usage (e.g. websites, ads, packaging), and present your work in a clean, professional portfolio that matches your clients‚Äô aesthetic.
Position your work as a tool for engagement, education, or storytelling ‚Äî not just visuals. Share metrics where possible (like watch time or conversions), explain the strategy behind each piece, and showcase your best work in a tightly edited reel tailored to your niche.
